DataElement.preferredDefinition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on the Berlin criteria for acute respiratory distress syndrome.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Disease Response Domain Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Assessment
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A domain for disease response evaluations._Progressive and life-threatening pulmonary distress in the absence of an underlying pulmonary condition, usually following major trauma or surgery. Cases of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome are not included in this definition._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: Progressive and life-threatening pulmonary distress in the absence of an underlying pulmonary condition, usually following major trauma or surgery. Cases of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome are not included in this definition.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Berlin Criteria for Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A consensus definition for acute respiratory distress syndrome that establishes three mutually exclusive categories of ARDS based on degree of hypoxemia, radiographic severity, respiratory system compliance, positive end-expiratory pressure, and corrected expired volume per minute._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A form of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that is marked by severe hypoxemia. Based on the Berlin criteria, onset must occur within one week of a clinical insult or there must be evidence of new or worsening respiratory symptoms. Chest imaging reveals bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema that are not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules. Respiratory failure is not fully explained by heart failure or fluid overload and objective assessment, e.g. echocardiography, is required to exclude hydrostatic edema if no risk factor is present. Additionally, oxygenation as measured by a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) to the fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) is equivalent to 100 mm Hg or less with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of at least 5 cm of water (Ranieri VM et al., JAMA. 2012;307(23):2526-2533). Severe ARDS may be associated with cytokine release syndrome.

Concepts.definition: A form of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that is marked by severe hypoxemia. Based on the Berlin criteria, onset must occur within one week of a clinical insult or there must be evidence of new or worsening respiratory symptoms. Chest imaging reveals bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema that are not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules. Respiratory failure is not fully explained by heart failure or fluid overload and objective assessment, e.g. echocardiography, is required to exclude hydrostatic edema if no risk factor is present. Additionally, oxygenation as measured by a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) to the fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) is equivalent to 100 mm Hg or less with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of at least 5 cm of water (Ranieri VM et al., JAMA. 2012;307(23):2526-2533). Severe ARDS may be associated with cytokine release syndrome.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A form of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that is marked by moderate hypoxemia. Based on the Berlin criteria, onset must occur within one week of a clinical insult or there must be evidence of new or worsening respiratory symptoms. Chest imaging reveals bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema that are not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules. Respiratory failure is not fully explained by heart failure or fluid overload and objective assessment, e.g. echocardiography, is required to exclude hydrostatic edema if no risk factor is present. Additionally, oxygenation as measured by a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) to the fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) is equivalent to between 100 and 200 mm Hg with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of at least 5 cm of water (Ranieri VM et al., JAMA. 2012;307(23):2526-2533).

Concepts.definition: A form of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that is marked by moderate hypoxemia. Based on the Berlin criteria, onset must occur within one week of a clinical insult or there must be evidence of new or worsening respiratory symptoms. Chest imaging reveals bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema that are not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules. Respiratory failure is not fully explained by heart failure or fluid overload and objective assessment, e.g. echocardiography, is required to exclude hydrostatic edema if no risk factor is present. Additionally, oxygenation as measured by a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) to the fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) is equivalent to between 100 and 200 mm Hg with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of at least 5 cm of water (Ranieri VM et al., JAMA. 2012;307(23):2526-2533).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A form of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that is marked by mild hypoxemia. Based on the Berlin criteria, onset must occur within one week of a clinical insult or there must be evidence of new or worsening respiratory symptoms. Chest imaging reveals bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema that are not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules. Respiratory failure is not fully explained by heart failure or fluid overload and objective assessment, e.g. echocardiography, is required to exclude hydrostatic edema if no risk factor is present. Additionally, oxygenation as measured by a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) to the fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) is equivalent to between 200 and 300 mm Hg with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) or continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) of at least 5 cm of water (Ranieri VM et al., JAMA. 2012;307(23):2526-2533).

Concepts.definition: A form of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that is marked by mild hypoxemia. Based on the Berlin criteria, onset must occur within one week of a clinical insult or there must be evidence of new or worsening respiratory symptoms. Chest imaging reveals bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema that are not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules. Respiratory failure is not fully explained by heart failure or fluid overload and objective assessment, e.g. echocardiography, is required to exclude hydrostatic edema if no risk factor is present. Additionally, oxygenation as measured by a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) to the fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) is equivalent to between 200 and 300 mm Hg with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) or continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) of at least 5 cm of water (Ranieri VM et al., JAMA. 2012;307(23):2526-2533).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Berlin Criteria for Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Category
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition:
A consensus definition for acute respiratory distress syndrome that establishes three mutually exclusive categories of ARDS based on degree of hypoxemia, radiographic severity, respiratory system compliance, positive end-expiratory pressure, and corrected expired volume per minute.

:A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
